bestBHT.bht: The phrase signifying what death he should die points to Jesus being lifted up from the earth on the accursed tree. This suggests that His words express not just the fact of His death, but also the kind or manner in which it would occur, namely, through crucifixion. While there may be different interpretations regarding the depth of meaning behind this expression, it is evident that Jesus intended to emphasize the significance of His crucifixion as a central aspect of His impending death.

Henry Alford: The words here can hardly point to more than the external circumstances of His death.
Some have found in the expression the whole consequences and character of His Death.
St. John does not say that this was all that the 'lifting up' meant, but that it was its first and obvious reference.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: death he should die—that is, "by being lifted up from the
Archibald T. Robertson: Signifying (σημαινων). Present active participle of σεμαινω, old verb to give a sign (σημειον) as in Acts 25:27, and the whole phrase repeated in John 18:32 and nearly so in John 21:19.

The indirect question here and in John 18:32 has the imperfect εμελλεν with present infinitive rather than the usual present μελλε retained while in John 21:19 the future indicative δοξασε occurs according to rule.
The point in ποιω (qualitative relative in the instrumental case with θανατω) is the Cross (lifted up) as the kind of death before Christ.
John Gill: These are the words of the evangelist, interpreting the design of Christ in the above words, thereby signifying what death he should die.
The phrase of being lifted up from the earth, not only signified his death, but the kind, or manner of it, that it should be by crucifixion.
A person crucified being stretched forth upon a cross, and that erected, was lifted up between earth and heaven.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse in question is a statement made by Jesus, which the commentator suggests refers to the external circumstances of His death. While some have speculated that the expression holds a deeper meaning regarding the consequences and character of His death, the commentator argues that John is emphasizing its initial and obvious reference. The phrase signifying what death he should die implies that Jesus would be lifted up from the earth on the accursed tree, referring to the crucifixion. In this way, Jesus's words not only point to His death, but also the manner in which it would happen, with Him being stretched forth and lifted up between earth and heaven.

The phrase signifying what death he should die suggests that Jesus would be lifted up from the earth on the accursed tree. Some have argued that this expression holds a deeper meaning regarding the consequences and character of His death, while others believe it simply refers to the external circumstances. Regardless, Jesus's words highlight the crucifixion and the manner in which His death would occur, with Him being stretched forth and lifted up between earth and heaven.

The phrase signifying what death he should die reflects on Jesus being lifted up from the earth on the accursed tree. This suggests that His words indicate both the form and nature of His death, with Him being stretched forth and lifted up between earth and heaven. While some debate whether this expression implies deeper implications about the consequences and character of His death or simply refers to the external circumstances, it is clear that Jesus's words emphasize the crucifixion as the means by which He would die.

The phrase signifying what death he should die points to Jesus being lifted up from the earth on the accursed tree. This suggests that His words express not just the fact of His death, but also the kind or manner in which it would occur, namely, through crucifixion. While there may be different interpretations regarding the depth of meaning behind this expression, it is evident that Jesus intended to emphasize the significance of His crucifixion as a central aspect of His impending death.

The phrase signifying what death he should die emphasizes that Jesus would be lifted up from the earth on the accursed tree. This points to His death by crucifixion. While there may be speculation about the deeper implications of this expression, Jesus's words clearly highlight the manner in which His death would occur. It is undeniable that the crucifixion is central to understanding the significance of Jesus's impending death.
